column3: and I recently got into the MMO scene after largely ignoring multiplayer gaming for a majority of my life. Besides WoW I pretty much played single player games. That all changed with Destiny
column4: and after I did everything that could be done
column5: I searched for my next fix. From its early on
column6: The Division felt like it was marketed to the Destiny guys that ran out of things to do and wanted a a solid MMO gaming experience with plenty of things to do
column7: and the Dark Zone to keep players hooked.

column2: if not a little uninspired. Shooting feels a little bland
column3: aiming isn't as tight as it feels like it should be. This could just be my problem
column4: however. Once I started reaching higher levels and getting better weapons
column5: this got a little better; I don't know if I got more skilled or the weapons alleviated some of those issues
column6: or a combination of both. The cover mechanic functions as well. I found myself pulling out of cover on accident and getting nailed
column7: but with time
column8: I got much better with paying attention to what I was doing. Enemy AI seems competent. You have particular enemies that employ particular strategies. For instance
column9: there are 'brawler' types that will rush you hard with a bat or a shotgun. You've got your typical cover fire shooters
column10: the occasional sniper
column11: and then your elite guys which can fall in any category but have the added benefit of additional health and armor. The enemies are bullet sponges
column12: but not so much to a fault. I would say that have the right amount of health to allow them to deploy strategic attacks on your group without feeling overpowered in the process.

column1: The Division's structure and systems are elaborate
column2: and you'll probably feel overwhelmed once you make it to the Manhattan for the first time. Everywhere you walk your map is bombarded with objectives; phones ringing
column3: agent locations
column4: encounters
column5: main missions
column6: etc. There's an initial shock of all this stuff to do
column7: and feeling overwhelmed about where to even start. Once you get going
column8: it gets really engaging. Matchmaking is excellent. It just works. I haven't had a single issue finding a team to tackle a mission or just do objectives around the map. It seems like there's a good amount of content built into the base game
column9: but there will be those gamers that blow through all this content in no time; in fact I'm sure there's plenty that have already done so by the time I write this review.

column1: Visual/Audio presentation is top notch. The graphics are really good. But more importantly
column2: the ambiance and detail are remarkable. A lot of heart went into making this game look like it does. Everything is so deliberate
column3: each room
column4: hallway and alley has a story to tell. There's no copy and paste asset creation here; not that I could tell anyway. The attention to detail goes above and beyond what I've seen in many games in years past. In a lot ways
column5: it reminds me of the experience I had playing Bioshock for the first time- from the aspect of attention to detail. Sound is equally as good. The ambient music blends methodically in the background; exactly what you want it to do- it adds intensity when needed and fades away while you're taking a walk through Times Square. The sound effects are great- I particularly like the satisfying crunch of a headshot with a marksman rifle. From a presentation perspective
column6: this game gets a 5/5
column7: no doubt about it.

column1: The one part of the game I cannot comment on as of yet is the Dark Zone. I understand this is a huge draw for the PvP crowd
column2: and offers a ton of great rewards for those to go exploring through it. I just haven't ventured there just yet
column3: I'm level 17 at the moment
column4: and I'm still enjoying the PvE and the world's ambiance.

column1: I'd definitely recommend this game to those that were big fans of Destiny
column2: I can see it catering to that gamer easily. As a big single player gamer
column3: I'd also encourage other single player gamers to give The Division a try. It's a blast to play by yourself
column4: but I find it to be so much better playing with a group. I personally play almost everything with a group
column5: unless I'm out exploring or trying to pick up some of the collectibles throughout the environment. If you knew me
column6: you'd know how much of a compliment this is to The Division- to get me to WANT to play with others. It's a great game
column7: a fun way to pass the time
column8: and a heck of an experience so far. Try it out
column9: you won't be disappointed!"^4^February 6

^55171751^1^0^"This game has a lot in common with lords of the fallen. I have had it for a week. I beat the intro tutorial level. Now on first mission. You have shrines located in different locationsfor saving and leveling up. I have been focused on leveling up to avoid getting stuck. Once you activate a shrine all human foes respawn. column4: spear
column5: axe

column2: ^36883863^12^6^"+ The game runs okay and feels great playing with a DS4. Offline mode. Definitely a great value for your money.

column1: - Zoomed in camera (compared to the PC version)
column2: FPS drops here and there
column3: and navigating the menus feels a bit clunky. Lacks a LOT of the core PC features. Cheaters are a major issue.

column1: Only buy this version if you're unable to play the PC version
column2: or if you choose to play offline or solo. Cheaters run rampant on the console versions and will go out of their way to grief you.One example
column3: some guy came into my game as I was doing a Torment 4 rift and as he started killing stuff
column4: I gained 1500 paragon levels within 25 seconds because he had edited gear on that added MASSIVE + XP per kill (which works for anyone in his party). Completely ruining my account as paragon levels are linked with all your characters. It's pretty obvious that the PS/XBOX versions are an afterthought for Blizzard. Seems like they could care less about cheaters on console
column5: because this has been an issue since D3 on PS3/360."^3^October 3

^25394893^1^8^"I haven't played FIFA since 02
column3: and back then it was fun. This could be the most frustrating game I have ever played.

column1: To start the controls seem as though they were made just to irritate. Shooting
column2: passing and lobbing are all press sensitive. Seems like a simple concept
column3: it is used in Madden and other EA games. However in FIFA a tap will leave the ball rolling slowly down field where it is easily intercepted. Hold the button for even a fraction of a second longer and the ball will sail into the stands. There is no finesses that the game boasts on the box.

column1: Next your controls change in an unperceived instant when you go from offense to defense. Another thing that is good in concept. But again it only leads to frustration. Circle is used to attack the player with possession
column2: it is also used to shoot. So when challenging your player will receive possession although it isn't apparent on the screen. The two players seem to still be challenging each other. Hit circle again to continue the challenge and you player launches the ball down field in an attempted shoot.

column1: Continuing on. You only control either the player with possession or the closest defender. You can change manually on D
column2: not on O. When I would attempt a long pass
column3: the player it was intended for would just stand in one spot making no attempt for the ball. Again a defender will just run in and take possession.

column1: Dribbling is also a nightmare. Players all have a star level. Attempt a skill out of their level and nothing happen. Even when I attempted 1 star moves my player would stumble on the ball or kick it out of their own reach. Most often though
column2: they simply would do nothing except run straight into a defender and lose possession.

column1: If you want to play FIFA
column2: download it on your smart phone. I gave this game too many attempts and now it is going up for sale."^1^July 14

first off let's get the basic stuff out of the way. Walmart.com shipping was fast and package came in perfect condition with the preorder bonus. Now on to the game review.

column1: Horizon Zero Dawn contains everything I really could have imagined or wanted
column2: and then some! Breathtaking graphics:  Check!  Fun and addicting gameplay:  Check!  Massive open world:  Double Check!!  While I'm probably 10 hours in
column3: I feel like I've just started the story
column4: which is massive in scale. So far the story is amazing as well! No words can describe my shock when I opened up the map for the first time and realized this massive area I was exploring was just a little speck compared to how big the map really was! (Still haven't opened up the whole map yet) Well I could talk about this game all day so I'm gonna wrap this up by saying that if you weren't sure whether or not to get this game
column5: GET IT! You will be glad you did.

column1: -Huge open world with many many things to find and explore
-(bonus pro) The character models are ridiculously well animated!

-Only small con I have is the jumping mechanic can feel a bit stiff and awkward sometimes and sometimes I found scaling things a little awkward and slow but it didn't detract from the overall gameplay.
-I'd give it a 4.9/5 Arrows! Seriously this game is amazing!!!

column2: ^49869069^4^2^"Awesome game play."^5^March 21
^49869069^3^2^"Storytelling: It's great
column3: probably next to The Last of Us. However
column4: the lip sync is off at times
column5: could be annoying to some people. To me
column6: it's a flaw which can be overlooked given there are so many other things to enjoy in this game. I think dialogues are very well written and voice acting is good as well.

column1: Music: Pretty good music throughout the game
column2: love Aloy's theme.

column1: Landscape: It's a vast and beautiful open world for you to explore. Save points are throughout the map. Fast travel is easy and accessible. There are different hostile and non-hostile things to kill all over the place.
Graphics: The best till date on any console and for any games that I've played thus far or watched youtube videos
column2: be it Rise of the Tomb Raider
column3: Uncharted 4
column4: Elder Scrolls Online
column5: Witcher 3 etc.

column1: Machines: There are different kinds of machines which are beautifully designed
column2: with the right strategy you can kill most of them relatively easily
column3: gotta learn how to hunt when you play the game!

column1: Weapons: An Interesting selection that goes well with the game theme. Almost each type of weapon has something to offer
column2: it's up to you how to use the selection that's at your disposal. I personally enjoyed most of the weapons. I usually prefer bows over guns and that's another reason for me to absolutely love this game.

column1: Armors: Usually I do not like armors offered in most of the games after experiencing the Daedric armor in Skyrim. However
column2: this game offers quite a few armors that are absolutely beautiful. I did enough farming which I enjoyed
column3: unlike Elder Scrolls Online
column4: to buy each and every weapon and armor that was available.

column1: Game style: You can run and kill some machines or go for stealth kills using the spear
column2: but for some
column3: you need more finesse which would require traps and ranged attacks. I personally enjoyed different strategies to exploit most weapons.

column1: Skills: I think skill tree is a bit brief but well explained and pretty relevant which makes it easy to know where you want to prioritize to use your skill points unlike some games which have too much going on and you have little clue how to get most out of your skill points as some upgrades are little to no use.

Crafting: This is very well laid out and you can do it on the go as long as you have enough resources. I always had plenty of resources because I spent quite a bit of time just exploring the beautiful world and farming for the resources. I think I like the fact that I didn't have to gather hundreds of things like some other RPG games.
Collectibles: I think people who like to find each and every collectible will enjoy this aspect of the game because there are a lot of collectibles scattered all over the huge open world.
Inventory: The interface is beautiful and easy to navigate. However
column2: the modification section is a bit unorganized where uncommon
column3: rare and very rare mods are not sorted appropriately.

column2: comes handy in the heat of a fight.

column1: Photo Mode: You can use this feature to capture beautiful screenshots throughout the game. I've posted a couple of screenshots here. My current PS4 Theme is custom using one of the many screenshots that I have from the game.

Difficulty: I played the game on the normal difficulty which I think was neither too hard nor too easy. I saw a couple of people giving the game bad rating because they did not like the difficulty level (either too difficult or too easy)
column2: to me this is in your control and you can choose whatever difficulty you want. If you need some challenge or want to take it easy you can change the difficulty.

column1: Issues: I have not experienced any issues while playing the game. I think some people experienced game crashing during the intro video which I think has already been addressed.

Overall I think this game is a perfect blend of primal and futuristic world with amazing graphics and story to give you an amazing gaming experience. I think each aspect of the game is beautiful and what makes this game amazing is the fact that each piece goes very well together. There is a lot to do and this game is fun all the way. I did not mind logging in countless hours into this game."^5^May 1

column2: ^49302431^3^0^"I received as a gift from a very lovely lady. So I am going to review this.

column1: Upon first impressions the game looks amazing and feels like a desolate GTA. The controls are responsive and it is nice to see movement ultimately unhindered. The theme is awesome. It feels like you are thrown in as an agent. Playing further it appears broken due to the DPS factor.

column2: when playing a shooter DPS should not be involved when dealing with human beings.

column1: Lets take pen and pad RPG's. We will use Palladium.
They use damage capacities. SDC versus MDC.
Structural damage capacity versus Mega damage capacity. An unprotected human body has SDC allotted to each part of the body. At 1 to 5 SDC per slot.
Most weapons do 1d6 SDC. This means if hit by a weapon in an unprotected part
column2: the part is generally destroyed. Arm blew off
column3: head blown off
column4: etc.

column1: I must saying having to dump entire clips into someones head while his friends are flanking is a big dip to the realism or fun factor. This game is no Metal Gear.
Because of the DPS mechanics a headshot is not a headshot
column2: even though the enemy is wearing a hoodie. If the enemy had on a kevlar helmet I would give some slack. To me this is a broken aspect of the game and I must rate it low.

column1: Crisp! very good frame rate for me. The lighting and shadowing make things feel almost real. A joy to look at. From the clothes to the actual hair textures for different people.

column2: very ambient. Guns sound great. Reloading changing clips sounds wonderful. Big thumbs up for the sound

column2: ^50179422^30^8^"Summary: Few games have the honor of being as highly anticipated as No Man's Sky. What was promised was nothing short of revolutionary. The scope of the game was almost unfathomable. The sheer amount of freedom and discovery gamers looked forward to with this release is nothing short of the uncontrollable excitement a child experiences the night before Christmas. Does it deliver on all the promises? Yes and no is the best answer to that question.

column1: Graphics: The visuals are delightful and mostly on par with what you would expect from this title
column2: technically speaking. I felt that detail could be a little higher when being very close to things such as plants and terrain. The art style is fairly unique and the palette fits well. Most colors are slightly washed'
column3: or have a pastel feel to them
column4: adding to the unique sci-fi feel. There is a familiarity in some plants and creatures from planet to planet
column5: but that is to be expected to some extent when considering the scope of the game.

column1: Sound: The sound effects work well and are thought out. The technology sounds are appropriate and add to the ambience. The dynamic creature noises are interesting and even amusing at times. There's not a lot of background noises
column2: but what is there increases the realism. The sound track is nothing less than stellar and an absolute pleasure to experience in the game.  I thought it would have been neat on the PS4 to have the system feedback announcements come through the controller speaker.

column1: Gameplay: This is where gamers choose sides. I've seen a lot of negative feedback on the game
column2: both from gameplay and technical issues. In a time when MOBAs and high action shooters seem to reign supreme
column3: I was looking forward to a slower-pace exploration game. The gameplay can get monotonous for some due to the constant necessity to mine materials to charge your life support and other critical tools and systems. You fly to a new planet
column4: start scavenging materials
column5: possibly find monoliths and other cool discoveries that increase your knowledge of certain alien races
column6: go to another planet and repeat. A player can take extra time to interact with the alien species
column7: trade
column8: and upgrade their equipment
column9: which I find satisfying. I enjoy taking my time experiencing the different planet's characteristics
column10: making discoveries
column11: often renaming them
column12: and then uploading them from the world to see. As for the technical issues
column13: the game has crashed twice on my PS4 (which I'd not yet experienced a crash on my PS4 yet)
column14: and I've experience no issues on my PC. The framerate stutters a bit as the game is loading but after a few minutes the framerate seems solid and smooth.

column1: Final Thoughts: I think the game is a huge success and I love playing it. I love how small it makes you feel when accessing the galaxy map and how I can take as much time as I want exploring as long as I keep my critical equipment charged. I love discovering upgrades for my multi tool and finding really strange creatures. I also love not being forced into explosive combat situations all the time. Not everyone will love the game as I can see how some would find it tedious and monotonous
column2: but I
column3: for one
column4: am very pro-No Man's Sky. I love it and keep an eye out  you just might find one of the many planets I've discovered!"^5^August 15

column2: ^50179422^17^18^"Not bad but I should have waited. This will be a 30 dollar game."^4^August 10
^50179422^16^0^"Alright first off
column3: do not go to youtube and scope out the trailers they showed for the game they are mainly false. Find some actual footage of people playing the game to see how much they really left out! I have honestly played the game well over 100+ hours to give it it's fair try and before I could truly criticize it. They did have an update for the system a few months back called 'The Foundation Update' which did improve it a little but not up to the specs of where they showed it should be. If you're looking for 'Amazing graphics' this game will let you down in comparison to Next Gen games most are seeing lately. The only true factor is yes it is endless there is no way anyone even if they played it 50 years straight would ever come close to getting to all the planets. But
column4: on that note keep in mind as many planets as there are there maybe only a couple of dozen really because after you hit say the first 30 planets
column5: I doubt you find any others that will really stand out as unique they all have the same skins after that. But on a positive note
column6: it's truly great IF you love to do some exploration and just wonder around. There are many times I caught myself looking up at the sky in the night and seeing 5 planets all around me which was quite awesome simply because I said 'hey
column7: I wanna go there right now to any of them' and could. I hope this kinda gives you a good idea of what you're getting and honestly with the price drop
column8: it's worth it at $20. To any of the parents reading this
column9: aside from what is a toy laser gun to Mine objects with there isn't too much violence unless you're kid just likes shooting aliens and space ships."^3^February 17

column2: ^55432568^3^2^"HAS SO MUCH ACTION AND ADVENTURE"^5^March 7
^55432568^3^2^"This game is much different than any of the previous entries in the franchise as it is officially an open world game. It plays and feels like a Zelda game
column3: but the adventure is open and free for you to do any way you want. For instance
column4: the main objectives in this game are to free the spirits of the four champions killed by Calamity Ganon
column5: and then defeat Calamity Ganon. If you want you can simply go ahead and charge towards Hyrule Castle and fight Calamity Ganon. You aren't required to save the four champions. Everything else in this game is running around and exploring the gigantic overworld.

column1: My issue with this game is that there aren't really dungeons like in previous Zelda titles. The four champions are in what can best be described as mini dungeons
column2: and they aren't that difficult. Anyone who wants to explore many dungeons
column3: get cool items
column4: and fight awesome bosses will be disappointed. Another gripe of mine is that every weapon in the game
column5: including the Master Sword
column6: can break. Once a weapon breaks
column7: it vanishes and you have to pick something else up. While the Master Sword doesn't truly break in this fashion

^55885486^85^40^"I cannot believe there are full grown adults on here complaining that a kids game isnt good for adults. Sad.

this is an excellent game. There are four beautifully designed worlds filled with platformer style puzzles which are reminiscent of Super Mario 3D world. Interspersed throughout each world are the turn based strategy encounters (think xcom).  The battles are strategically challenging
column3: but there is an easy mode which can be toggled for individual battles if you are more interested in the story.

column1: The writing is filled with Paper Mario style humor. The music is energetic and engaging. The story is simplistic and is more rabbids focused although Mario is the main character and rabbids make up the majority of the enemies.
Overall the game is filled with hours of delightful gameplay and perhaps a fair bit of replay-ability.
I picked up the splatoon 2 switch bundle along with this game and we havent even played splatoon yet since were having so much fun with Mario and his zany rabbid friends."^5^September 9

column3: ignore the other people trashing this game. I got this game with my Switch and immediately got sucked into it. The gameplay is turn-based

column2: ^44676910^43^27^"I really enjoyed when 343 took over from Bungie with Halo 4. I felt 343 gave more personality to a character that was
column3: otherwise
column4: a blank template of a hero. With Halo 4 I could actually feel the relationship between the Chief and Cortana. But I don't know what happened with Halo 5. You barely see/play the Chief in favor of a really bland and uninteresting proxy... at least with the Arbiter you got an idea of his internal struggle. All the trailers led up to the Chief and Locke confronting each other (doesn't really happen). On top of that Locke was able to stand his ground against Chief in once scene... how is that possible? One was an elite soldier who is augmented... and the Chief is a soldier TRAINED FROM BIRTH
column5: augmented
column6: and then further enhanced by the Librarian... there is no way that Locke should have been able to last against the Chief
column7: even for two seconds. Now
column8: my complaints aside
column9: this isn't a bad game; for a Sci-Fi shooter it is pretty good
column10: it just isn't up to what you expect from a Halo game. If I could go back I would rent it instead of buying it though."^3^January 3

column3: just talking about gameplay this is by far one of the best feeling games I have ever played with its 60 fps. With the new mechanics and spartan abilities
column4: it still does feel like halo but with the added feeling that you actually now do feel like a spartan. The only issue for me is that AI friendlies are lacking quite a bit. During missions they act stupid half of the time not usually doing anything. They do not even shoot as much you would suspect. The campaign in my eyes is better than most people give credit. The graphics in this game are amazing and the gameplay is the most fun I have had in a long time playing a fps. The refresh of the multiplayer
column5: also
column6: I feel like has brought by the halo multiplayer that was loved so much so long ago. Even though they removed split-screen I feel this is not as much of a problem as people put it out to be as I tend to hate sharing a screen anyways on first person shooters. Halo is not the first game to reduce or get rid of split screen in the sole purpose of provide higher frame rates and better graphics. You want to play with friends? Get a couple tvs in the same room and duel it out."^5^October 29

^45702418^29^9^"So I didn't play Plants Vs Zombies Garden Warfare 1
column3: but I did play the phone game on iOS and Android so when I heard that there is a Plants Vs Zombies 2 game coming out for Xbox One
column4: I was pretty suspicious at first. However
column5: I got a chance to play the beta and it definitely impressed me.

column1: Overview of the game: This game is actually a fresh take on a shooter game with both multiplayer and a single player mode. Definitely a great improvement compared to the mobile game that they released. This is a full fledged shooter comparable to other hardcore shooter games such as Call of Duty
column2: Battlefield
column3: Halo
column4: etc. except that it is kid-friendly and instead of different guns and loadouts
column5: you have different plants and zombies with different abilities and attacks.

column1: I really like the innovative spin that they put on a typical shooter with their different plants and zombies with different types of attacks and abilities. It is definitely loads of fun with lots of replay value. I mainly played the multiplayer (because that is mainly what I was interested in) and even a veteran shooter gamer like me who played almost all shooters made such as COD
column2: Battlefield
column3: Halo
column4: Gears of War
column5: Resistance
column6: etc. enjoyed thoroughly. Best part about this is that this is kid-friendly for all of those protective parents who dont want their kids to play violent video games.

column2: I will have to say that this game should be priced like a typical arcade game (even though it is a fully polished game) because it would get a bigger fan base. So the price may be pretty steep
column3: but it is definitely an enjoyable game and gives you a fresh take on typical multiplayer shooters."^4^May 9

^44662950^26^4^"If you are a Lego fan
column3: both of their games and the toys then Lego Dimensions is definitely for you.

column2: it had been ages since I have played with my Legos
column3: however the joy of putting this little gamepad together has brought up all those memories from before I went to college and I am starting now a Lego spree...

column2: its your average Lego Game experience. You choose your character
column3: jump and solve puzzles however Dimensions does make it more interesting than before since you now have to solve puzzles in the game and in your Toy Pad by switching your toys around.

column1: It allows local CO-OP which is great
column2: since it allows me to play with my girlfriend on the same screen.

column1: The only downside here is the high price tag attached to the other packs
column2: which sooner or later we have to buy since some parts of the game require that we have characters with different abilities.

column1: NOTE: these extra toys are not required for the story missions
column2: at least not so far for me. You are given an option during the levels and open worlds to 'rent' the necessary character for a few seconds in exchange for some game currency (that you get from playing and stuff)
column3: this is usually enough for you to access specific areas that require a laser for example or someone small to crawl through a hole - which is a great feature."^4^January 3

^37202059^3^0^"If you have never played a Lego game before
column3: this is as good a place as any to start. If you have played
column4: then this should be very familiar to you. Me and my son have been playing this game for a while now
column5: and while we were able to play through the main game in a day
column6: there are many more things to do after the conclusion of the story mode. The levels are all unlocked for free play (playing through the level again with different characters whose abilities can unlock new things you didn't have access to the first time through)
column7: but not only that
column8: there are many other missions available from characters that are hanging out in the menu hubs. Unlike Lego Marvel Superheroes
column9: there is no open world free roam as you were able to do in New York City
column10: however you are able to visit other locations to find new challenges and characters. Another new and welcome innovation is that if a character like Batman or Robin is required to change their suits to complete a task
column11: you do not have to open the menu to change the costume
column12: but instead approach the challenge and hit the prompted button (B button) and it automatically changes to the correct costume.

column1: There are quite a few new and exciting characters as well
column2: many of whom I've never heard of
column3: and many voice and lego character cameos by folks who have been associated with some of the DC franchises or comic book world. The controls are fluid and smooth
column4: similar to Marvel and the story does a good job of keeping things fresh and interesting with the humor that Lego games have come to be known for. I gave the game a challenging rating because there are some missions whose solutions are not always obvious and you have to perform a bit of trial and error to discover the correct path. Some folks might be deterred by this (as my son was at times) but we have yet to encounter something that we could not accomplish without a little thought and the proper character.

column2: a great game that has provided me and my son with many enjoyable hours of gameplay.
and happy building

^45611534^5^0^"Fallout 4 is a open world shooter with a stellar story line. It starts in your house in a place called sanctuary with your wife and son. You can model your character and change your gender. The world they live in is powered by nuclear energy which eventually causes a fallout. Then your character wakes up in a vault with his wife in front of him and a guy walks up and takes his son and kills the wife. Then the husband makes his way out of the vault and when he gets out he sees nothing but wasteland. He goes down to the town in search of his robot codsworth. He finds him and ask him what happened and where is his son. The robot responds look in diamond city. On his way to diamond city he finds this dog named dogmeat. He and the dog join together and make their way to diamond city. In the game there is perks that help you and armor and weapons to protect you from dangerous creatures and mutant humans. The game mechanics are smooth and feel good. There is a variety of weapons and missions to do. Overall i give it a 9/10 rating and definitely worth buying."^5^February 21

^44662950^26^4^"If you are a Lego fan
column3: both of their games and the toys then Lego Dimensions is definitely for you.

column2: it had been ages since I have played with my Legos
column3: however the joy of putting this little gamepad together has brought up all those memories from before I went to college and I am starting now a Lego spree...

column2: its your average Lego Game experience. You choose your character
column3: jump and solve puzzles however Dimensions does make it more interesting than before since you now have to solve puzzles in the game and in your Toy Pad by switching your toys around.

column1: It allows local CO-OP which is great
column2: since it allows me to play with my girlfriend on the same screen.

column1: The only downside here is the high price tag attached to the other packs
column2: which sooner or later we have to buy since some parts of the game require that we have characters with different abilities.

column1: NOTE: these extra toys are not required for the story missions
column2: at least not so far for me. You are given an option during the levels and open worlds to 'rent' the necessary character for a few seconds in exchange for some game currency (that you get from playing and stuff)
column3: this is usually enough for you to access specific areas that require a laser for example or someone small to crawl through a hole - which is a great feature."^4^January 3

column2: ^44662950^17^11^"I haven't stopped playing. Love how you can switch out characters as needed. Trying to figure out how to defeat some of bad guys is a bit tough but still an awesome game. Hope they continue to make more playable levels."^5^December 6
^44662950^15^0^"This game is so much fun

^26680690^8^0^"Lego Marvel Super Heroes is a fantastic game. If you have played any of the other Lego video games you know what to expect. This one however has a TON of content. There are 15 story missions (by my count
column3: I may be slightly off)
column4: each pretty long. Even once you beat the story
column5: you are just beginning. There is SO much more to do if you want to get all the collectables
column6: unlock every character
column7: etc. Speaking of characters
column8: there is a MASSIVE amount of them. Seriously
column9: watch a youtube video of this game and see for yourself. You will need them too
column10: because to get 100% in this game you will need a hero that can reflect lasers
column11: someone who can control minds
column12: someone who can sneak past security cameras
column13: someone who can freeze water into bridges... Really
column14: the list goes on. And the best part... going back and getting all the items hidden throughout the levels is actually FUN. It doesn't feel like a chore like most games.

column1: All that would be a fantastic game
column2: and I haven't even mentioned that you can run around New York City between missions and play around. There are a ton of side missions
column3: hidden items
column4: unlockable characters and vehicles
column5: etc
column6: strewn around the city. I've spent an hour just roaming around before remembering that I had a world to save.

column1: This game has drop-in/drop-out multiplayer (on the xbox one that I use
column2: I can't speak for every system) that makes multiplayer just the best. You can just jump right into a game with the press of a button
column3: no pausing
column4: no menus. I wish more games had this functionality.

column1: The only downsides might be that it's pretty family friendly. The jokes are all age appropriate (usually a little cheesy) and there isn't any blood and guts. This might scare off the 'hardcore gamers' who live only for hyper violent games and scoff at anything 'less'. I really can't praise this game enough though
column2: and if you are looking for a fun game to play as a family
column3: this might just be it for you. And honestly
column4: this is pretty fun to play alone late at night when everyone else is sleeping."^5^February 2

column1: Black Ops 3 takes place in the year 2065 a time where soldiers are given cybernetic enhancements to battle against robotic super soldiers. Because of this there are more controls for you to learn how to use
column2: so if you are still not comfortable with the basics
column3: this game might be a challenge. While on duty you will be shooting
column4: jumping
column5: and sliding all across the battlefield.

column1: Black Ops 3 has 3 main game modes: campaign
column2: multiplayer
column3: and zombies. The campaign tells the story of you and your partner traveling across the world to carry out missions for the CIA. multiplayer is a competitive online game mode where you fight people in different game modes including: team deathmatch
column4: capture the flag
column5: and domination. Multiplayer is best played when you have an online connection otherwise you are just fight bots. Zombies is a gamemode where you fight off a zombie horde with the guns you find on the wall and mystery box. With every bullet that hits a zombie the more points you get to use to buy better guns
column6: perks
column7: and weapon upgrades.

column1: The  DLC in Black Ops 3 makes the players experience more enjoyable
column2: but is not required to play. If you buy any DLC pack it will come with 5 maps: 4 for multiplayer and 1 for the zombies gamemode. Most of the multiplayer maps are nothing special
column3: but if you are a big fan of zombies then DLC is a must.

column7: humans vs bots
column8: horde 3.0. They've introduced booster packs (which I'm not a fan of) which are cards that add perks to the game. In the past
column9: the series allowed you to unlock new player models and skin weapons as rewards for progressing through any online play (including campaign). Now it's all choked through the booster packs. You can earn gear credits for winning or successfully completing goals in versus modes. It takes anywhere from 4-8 hours to rack up enough credits to afford these rewards. How they pipeline you is to purchase these pack instead. They have almost no effect to the game play
column10: with the exception of the horde skills. Horde skill are cards that allow you to buff skill sets of the archetype you pick to survive with (solider
column11: heavy
column12: engineer
column13: sniper
column14: scout). There is also a season pass available for an additional heavy cost
column15: but holds no true value. All maps come out a few weeks earlier for pass holders to play on with special community events. They are later released to the full community to play online for free. Over-all
column16: I like this game. I stink at the multiplayer and wish I had more friends that I could play with. But such is life for a middle aged person with a family. The end."^4^November 25

^47187984^2^10^"This review is for the XBOX One version of Star Wars Battlefront.
I'm a huge fan of Star Wars and have played all of them going back to the first 1980s arcade versions. Now that being said
column3: I can tell you that the game controls are HORRIBLE
column4: the WORST I've ever used in any Star Wars game
column5: especially for the flying vehicles.

column1: You cannot map individual control buttons. The one that bugs me the most is the left or right stick as your only choice your power/speed control button. It would be much better if it could have other button options like being on one of the trigger buttons. Also
column2: the flying vehicles are very mushy and erratic when compared to games like Ace Combat
column3: HAWX
column4: and even the 1983 arcade version of Star Wars. Basically
column5: I find many of the controls for this game somewhat clumsy.

column2: I bought it at Game Stop and when I tried to return it after 5 days they refused. They only allow used games to be returned within 7 days
column3: so GAME STOP BUYERS BEWARE! If you must have it
column4: wait and get it used from Game Stop so you can return it within 7 days if unhappy
column5: or get it from someone who has a fair return policy. Also there are a lot of video glitches in the cut scenes and in the game play. I'M VERY FREAKING UNHAPPY WITH THIS GAME!"^2^December 18

column2: ^25394847^64^17^"Let me first off state that I have been playing First Person Shooter Games for the last 12 years starting back in the days of Golden Eye

column6: Reach

column8: Black OPs
column9: Modern Warfare 3
column10: to Black Ops 2. I have always been mainly an online player and skipped the campaigns. I prefer real life competition. I consider myself to be a top gamer and try to always come in first place every game I play. In Black OPS 2 I was rated a Master ranking for Team Death match. Currently I own the Xbox 360
column11: PS3 and the new Xbox One. Now to Battlefield 4

column1: When this game was first released
column2: there were many bugs made the game feel incomplete and would hold back your complete satisfaction with the game. It is now about a month later and most of the bugs are gone. Some of the bugs were not being able to save the campaign mode at all. I was two hours deep into the campaign already and tried to save thinking I could come back later. But to my surprise and dismay I had to start from the beginning again. I was not a happy camper. But its fixed now.

column1: Weapons and Guns - each weapon is much more realistic in this game than Call of Duties. You have to account for bullet drop from long distances
column2: fire rate
column3: leading the target more when they are moving
column4: and there is a lot more customization of each weapon with different attachments and barrels.

column1: Although there isn't kill streaks that give you a super power up like a chopper
column2: pred drone
column3: UAV
column4: and care package
column5: ect the game includes different starting packages that are completely customizable. I play as a medic so I can revive people when they die within five seconds plus dish out health packets to damaged teammates. There is also a ammo 'supplies' class and a 'recon' and 'engineer class. Each have their own pros that they bring to the table. Have a team together online and they can work together with the different classes very well.

column1: Overall I think the game has much more versatility
column2: action
column3: more enjoyable than Call of Duty could hope to be. I heard many of my friends who tried to get me to play Battlefield over Call of Duty say this to me. Call of Duty is for kids Battlefield is for adults. I couldn't agree more after playing it.

column2: you will not regret it."^5^December 24

^25394878^4^4^"Don't buy this if you're looking for racing simulation  la Forza or Gran Turismo. There is no departure here for the next gen platforms. This game follows Need For Speeds tried and true super fast arcade style racing

column4: spectacular crashes and over the top speed bump and hit racing. The formula is dead on and it works
column5: all while looking fantastic on next gen systems. Improved lighting
column6: beautiful cars that get authentically dirty as you race
column7: fantastic weather effects
column8: heart pumping engine noises
column9: overall gorgeous visuals and crisp audio. The controls are a little loose as exoected from a nfs game
column10: but they work here. If you enjoy fun racing without the simulation
column11: this game is for you."^4^March 9

column2: ^50259740^4^4^"Right out of the gate this is NOT a child friendly game! As the M rating states this is a mature game with violent death scenes and imagery that may not be suitable. That said its up to the parent to make the call but from experience I can tell you the animations are very graphic and very detailed. Now
column3: on to the game. Having played the alpha
column4: closed beta
column5: and open beta I can say this for certain. This is an extremely fast paced run and gun first person shooter as one would expect from the older games. Speed can be modified to tailor to every gamers liking but as with most games of this nature the slower and sedentary you are the more you will have to respawn. The single player campaign boasts a huge 12-15 hr average run time. For those that are fans of the genre you know standard single player campaign is average 8-9 hours. For the old school doom players. The multiplayer is more of a quake arena and unreal tournament meets call of duty mashup. It retains the blistering speed of doom but includes the load out system of more modern shooters. So don't expect to be running into a match with your bfg and 20 rounds. As with all doom games minus the addition of doom three this game completely does away with reloading and just gives you a total ammo count which you can replenish ammo by picking up boxes as usual or preforming the new 'glory kills' these are kills in which after you damage the opponent enough they flash. Once you run to the flashing opponent and melee him you are treated to a gory yet satisfying animation that usually depending on what angle you are approaching the enemy winds up with you gaining health
column6: armor
column7: and ammo. As previously stated these are extremely graphic. All in all I love the game and my time with it is amazing and the new snap map editor which allows infinite possibilities for a player to create their own map and upload it is a great touch. Beef up the strength of the enemies and you and four friends can run through the hardest level you can dream up. This for me is what doom 3 should've been."^5^May 12

^10986107^7^2^"i recently got this game for free in the mail through the promotion with buying guitar hero 5. as far as gameplay goes it's the same that guitar hero fans have come to love. as far as the game goes as a whole it feels very rushed and incomplete. i'm not sure if it's incomplete but it definitely feels that way because it doesnt have the same overall feel as guitar hero metallica did. it's more like the older aerosmith game. theres no story and mostly when you beat the game it doesnt feel like you've accomplished anything. in order to beat the game you must complete every song on the track listing
column3: which there doesn't seem to be enough of either. there's somewhere around 25 tracks from van halen and a short list of mostly mediocre tracks from opening acts. by far the worst track listing yet for a guitar hero game. personally i think since they set the new standard so high with guitar hero 5 that they fell very short with van halen. they have taken a few steps back instead of following up with the graphics and gameplay features of 5. like i said b4 i dont know if this is basically a beta version they gave out for free and will polish it up b4 release this christmas but if not and this is the final product then i say save your money for another guitar hero title or perhaps one of the rock band games. the only way i can see spending 60$ ont his game is if you are a huge fan of van halen and just have to have it or to complete your collection of guitar hero games like myself (i'm a big fan of guitar hero and have all of them but smash hits). so i hope this ehlps all of you decide whether or not to buy it. personally i'd say borrow it from someone you know that has it already through the promotion or wait till it's rentable b4 purchase. overall i give it 3 1/2 stars out of 5. it's not a bad game it just falls short of the quality we have all come to expect from Guitar hero."^3^October 9

column2: ^10986107^3^1^"When I pop in a Band-Centric Guitar Hero game
column3: I expect to be treated to a visual and musical time capsule full of all of the band's definitive moments
column4: a decent collection of their songs spanning their career
column5: and a treasure chest of little known facts
column6: rare memorabilia
column7: and well
column8: some evidence that the band itself was involved with the game. After bringing Guitar Hero: Van Halen to a close
column9: I don't see my criteria met. Instead
column10: I ran through my third (fourth if I bought Smash Hits) Guitar Hero game of 2009
column11: and after finishing it
column12: I don't feel like I've learned much about Van Halen itself.

column2: anyone who hasn't played a guitar hero game shouldn't start with Van Halen. If you have this game
column3: you either A) Followed up on the free voucher offer after purchasing Guitar hero 5
column4: B) Are a Van Halen fan
column5: estatic to see them in their own music game
column6: or C) Proving it's possible to play Guitar Hero all year round
column7: since a new game is released by the time you finish the previous one.

column1: If this is your first foray into Guitar Hero
column2: or any music game for that matter
column3: I highly recommend picking up one from the main series in the series first. For the same price as GH: Van Halen
column4: Guitar Hero 5 has 85 songs from a larger variety of artists
column5: while Guitar Hero 4 (World Tour)
column6: just a year older
column7: has 86. Since we're dealing with a band-centric game
column8: expect to hear a lot of Van Halen
column9: and not much else.

column1: The same familiar formula of playing is present here
column2: but without getting too technical
column3: Van Halen's game engine is the same as GH Metallica's
column4: making it older than Guitar Hero 5. This is all well and good
column5: but it's an odd choice on Activision's part
column6: because it was released after GH 5. In my opinion
column7: this isn't as much of a setback
column8: because the controls feel a lot tighter under this engine compared to GH 5. The songs are note tracked pretty well. The difficulty curve steadily rises as you make your way through the set list
column9: alternating with a venue for guest artist tracks
column10: and a venue for Van Halen's music. There isn't a point where you'll ace one song and the following song will be so far over your head you won't know where to begin. The slider sections
column11: characterized by transparent notes connected by a clear rope
column12: are still pretty useless
column13: because they are just thrown in randomly
column14: or when you reach a very difficult section where the game expects you to use it
column15: its just easier to flail on the keys.

column2: most of us know what to expect with Guitar Hero
column3: so the only factor that handicaps Van Halen is it's presentation. I'm betting that Van Halen fans will be disappointed once they notice the game completely omits their bassist of 31 years
column4: Michael Anthony
column5: and their second vocalist who fronted the band for 13 years
column6: Sammy Hagar. While Anthony's absence can be overlooked (Metallica featured songs from all three of their Bassists
column7: so it could have been done here too)
column8: the decision not to include any work from Hagar effectively cuts off the chance to feature any songs from their albums after their last album with original and current front man
column9: David Lee Roth
column10: 1984. All this cutting
column11: trimming and removing results in a setlist that only features 25 of their songs
column12: with 3 of Eddie's solos. I believe the amount of material they've recorded from 1978 to 1998 should warrant more than 28 tracks. Tacked on are 19 songs from guest bands/artists
column13: some who have a questionable affiliation with VH
column14: coming to a grand total of 47 tracks.

column2: Van Halen's music is decent
column3: and fans of their legacy would quickly find a handful of their favorite tracks here. GH fan's prayers have finally been answered with the long overdue addition of Eddie's famed solo
column4: Eruption. Hang Em High
column5: Panama and Jump are all easily recognizable classics
column6: and are a blast to play. Guest tracks like Deep Purple's Space Truckin' and Queen's I Want It All complement Van Halen perfectly
column7: but oddballs like Stacy's Mom by Fountains of Wayne seem well
column8: out of place.

column1: Once you've played through all of the songs or just your favorites
column2: that's pretty much the end of the game. There's really no further indication of the band's involvement with this game
column3: which is very surprising. There's cheesy footage of the band in awkward mo-cap suits recording their movements on stage(a la Metallica)
column4: no rare pictures
column5: band interviews(Aerosmith)
column6: or even a hey
column7: thanks for playing our game! message from the band. Beyond playing the songs on our plastic instruments
column8: the only way we know its Van Halen is when the four of them are on the stage.

column1: Guitar Hero: Van Halen is a decent game when not stacked up against it's contemporaries. It continues to feature the great gameplay that Guitar Hero is known for. But since this game focuses on the legacy of a single band
column2: their presentation is just as important as the game itself. Players who know nothing of Van Halen's background will be treated to a history lesson that leaves out a handful of important events and people. In Van Halens case
column3: its inexcusable to not even mention the time and effort Michael Anthony and Sammy Hagar put in."^3^January 13

^44782727^4^9^"This review is for the XBOX One version of Star Wars Battlefront.
I'm a huge fan of Star Wars and have played all of them going back to the first 1980s arcade versions. Now that being said
column3: I can tell you that the game controls are HORRIBLE
column4: the WORST I've ever used in any Star Wars game
column5: especially for the flying vehicles.

column1: You cannot map individual control buttons. The one that bugs me the most is the left or right stick as your only choice your power/speed control button. It would be much better if it could have other button options like being on one of the trigger buttons. Also
column2: the flying vehicles are very mushy and erratic when compared to games like Ace Combat
column3: HAWX
column4: and even the 1983 arcade version of Star Wars. Basically
column5: I find many of the controls for this game somewhat clumsy.

column2: I bought it at Game Stop and when I tried to return it after 5 days they refused. They only allow used games to be returned within 7 days
column3: so GAME STOP BUYERS BEWARE! If you must have it
column4: wait and get it used from Game Stop so you can return it within 7 days if unhappy
column5: or get it from someone who has a fair return policy. Also there are a lot of video glitches in the cut scenes and in the game play. I'M VERY FREAKING UNHAPPY WITH THIS GAME!"^2^December 18

^44782727^2^10^"This review is for the XBOX One version of Star Wars Battlefront.
I'm a huge fan of Star Wars and have played all of them going back to the first 1980s arcade versions. Now that being said
column3: I can tell you that the game controls are HORRIBLE
column4: the WORST I've ever used in any Star Wars game
column5: especially for the flying vehicles.

column1: You cannot map individual control buttons. The one that bugs me the most is the left or right stick as your only choice your power/speed control button. It would be much better if it could have other button options like being on one of the trigger buttons. Also
column2: the flying vehicles are very mushy and erratic when compared to games like Ace Combat
column3: HAWX
column4: and even the 1983 arcade version of Star Wars. Basically
column5: I find many of the controls for this game somewhat clumsy.

column2: I bought it at Game Stop and when I tried to return it after 5 days they refused. They only allow used games to be returned within 7 days
column3: so GAME STOP BUYERS BEWARE! If you must have it
column4: wait and get it used from Game Stop so you can return it within 7 days if unhappy
column5: or get it from someone who has a fair return policy. Also there are a lot of video glitches in the cut scenes and in the game play. I'M VERY FREAKING UNHAPPY WITH THIS GAME!"^2^December 18

column1: There hasn't been a good baseball game on an XBOX since the 2K series. In fact the last baseball game I bought was 2K 2012. I figured this would be better because the XBOX ONE is an amazing console.

column2: because of the following.

column1: The game play on this is akin to Super Nintendo
column2: and I'm deadly serious. You have one static camera view and limited controls. You can't change the location of a pitch. The outer and batter glide around the box or mound when you move them. It is just silly. You press A to hit. You press A to pitch. I mean it's really lame.

column1: The graphics are worse than XBOX 360. There is no annoncer chatter in the background
column2: the crowds and stadiums lack any detail.

column1: Maybe kids will enjoy this. Little kids. Like 6 year olds.
I hate it...I would have rather lit my $30 on Fire."^1^April 14

column2: ^642826370^1^0^"I ignored the poor reviews of RBI Baseball 18 as I hung on to a glimmer of hope that folks were wrong in their harsh comments of the game.  It didn't take me but a couple hours to wish I would have heeded their warnings!

column1: RBI Baseball 18 starts with a cartoonish opening screen of Francisco Lindor and then progresses to a flashing MLB logo at the bottom right hand corner that seems to take 2 to 3 minutes to load.  After that 2 to 3 minutes the game opening screen loads and even after selections it takes another 2 to 3 minutes of loading time and some cheesy music and Atari era sounds before game play actually can begin.  So after 5-10 minutes you are hoping it is worth the wait and let the fun begin.
Before analyzing the game play let's start the complaints with the availability of practice/training or any other form of getting to know the controls like how to pitch
column2: bat
column3: run
column4: or field.  There is about a super short tutorial on pitching
column5: batting
column6: and running but nothing that would provide you skills beyond the very basic.  You have to pay attention to the splash screen (that is different each start up) on how what buttons are for certain actions but nothing that allows you to practice this use.

column1: Once you start play it takes maybe a minute each half inning for loading.  The batter and the pitcher move around like slots on a foosball table and the batter resets to the original position after each pitch.  There are no controls for placement of fielders though it doesn't matter as most the hits are predictable
column2: the weather is non-existent and probably wouldn't effect anything on this very basic game.  The ball in play is like a blip from pong and the players like robots as they chase a circle that increases or decreases with height of the ball.

column1: The calls of balls and strikes are Leisure Suit Larry era and most have took all of 2 minutes to program and oh forget about getting the names of the players mentioned
column2: walks to the mound
column3: or even a simple set of players in the dugout on foul balls or scoring reactions.  If you hit a home run you hardly even see where it landed
column4: distance
column5: or any other stat and just a head reaction from the pitcher with some lame music as you see the player round first and then heading home.

column1: If this review sounds boring then you hit it right on the head.  For 21st century sports gaming RBI Baseball 18 is a laugher!  But what should we expect from MLB with their below average phone apps
column2: team webpages
column3: and product storefront.

column1: I would bypass this game and buy a PS4 so you can play baseball that resembles 21st century sports gaming.  MLB should get out of the IT business and focus on the sport!"^1^April 24

It's a domino effect and the only thing these big companies understand is when money is being taken out of their wallet.

column1: The following forum has detailed information on the loading issue:
UbiSoft's Response to My Support Ticket Regarding This Issue
I purchased Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag on May 29th 2016 from WalMart.
When trying to fast travel to Nassau I became stuck in the Animus loading screen. Now my game will only load the Animus screen and I can do nothing else with it.

I've tried the quitting from the animus screen and then uninstalling and reinstalling Black Flag probably 7 times and it has not worked for me. I've deleted my save file and redownloaded it from the UbiSoft server. I've cleared my game cache. And I've tried using a different brand new copy of the game disc. Nothing has worked
column2: however
column3: and I am still stuck in the Animus loading screen. I have even left the screen sitting for over an hour to see if the game would load
column4: but it did not.

column1: I've looked on approximately 5 different forum posts about this same issue on several different sites and I've even read comments on YouTube videos concerning this issue and everyone is saying the same thing
column2: Nassau doesn't load and UbiSoft won't fix it.

column1: The only thing I haven't tried yet is downloading a copy from the XBox Live Store to see if that would work. That's why I'm writing today
column2: to see if you would be so kind as to provide me with a download code for my game so that I can give that option a try as a last resort.

column1: Emily B: Thank you for contacting Ubisoft Live Support. Please give me a moment to read your question
column2: and I'll be with you shortly.

column1: Emily B: I'm sorry to hear you've been having issues with Nassau. We actually do have some instructions on how to fix that.
Emily B: They're rather long though
column2: so I'll need to email them to you once the chat closes

column1: Emily B: If you still experience issues
column2: you can update your ticket or just hop into chat again

column1: Me: Can you email them to me now so I can read over them to see if it's something I haven't already tried?
Emily B: I just sent that email out
If you are having trouble loading into Nassau during the Sequence 3
column2: Memory 2 story mission
column3: please follow the steps below to resolve the issue:

column1: 1. Make sure your console is connected to the internet and you are connected to Xbox Live with an Xbox Gold or Silver account.
2. Insert the game disc and launch the game as you normally would to play it.
3. After the game has been launched
column2: quit the game and eject the disc.

column1: -The icon for the game should still show up in the Recently Played tiles below the large tile on the home screen.

column2: you may need to launch another App on the Xbox (such as the Xbox store) and then use the home button in the middle of the controller to leave the opened App. Doing this a couple of times should make the Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag icon eventually appear.

column1: 4. Scroll down to recently playede and highlight the Black Flag Tile.

column2: select the game icon
column3: press the Menu button again
column4: and select Uninstall.

column2: press the Xbox Home button in the middle of the controller.

column1: -You should still Black Flag in the Recently Played area
column2: but now dimmed.

column1: 7. Highlight Black Flag in recently played and presst menu button. You should then see an option to install the game.
-This will begin downloading the game from Xbox Live. Note: If there is not an install choice in that menu
column2: try launching the game
column3: and one of the options in the dialog that appears may be Install.

column1: 8. Once the game is fully installed
column2: put the disc back in the console and launch the game.

column1: You should now be able to continue playing and load into Nassau without issue.
Me: '6. Once the game is uninstalled
column2: press the Xbox Home button in the middle of the controller. -You should still Black Flag in the Recently Played area
column3: but now dimmed.'

^38662069^55^3^"First and foremost.  This device is being heavily sold and promoted as a 4K UHD Bluray and streaming device (as well as gaming console).

column1: The 4K UHD Bluray playback is crippled on the audio front unless you opt in to an unstable beta of the software that sometimes works.
Amazon Streaming is still not true 4k streaming on the Xbox One S.
4K UHD Bluray:  Out of the box
column2: the device claims to support Dlby TruHD and DTS:HD MA via internal decoding and then Multichannel PCM.  This is false.  It has been proven that it is impossible to get a True
column3: unaltered HD audio stream out of the Xbox One series of consoles even via PCM.  Further it has been proven that it actively damages HD audio as anything sampled at 96khz or higher is downsampled to 48khz.  This right here is a major failing.  Further the 4K UHD Spec states a player must be able to decode Immersive Audio formats and supply outputs to at least 2 height outputs or supply bitstream support which the Xbox One S is unable to provide out of the box.

column2: the player for 4K UHD Blurays has audio support worse than a normal Bluray player and does not meet the requirements to be 4k UHD Bluray player.  Both mentioned issues can be corrected by downloading the insider preview app
column3: select to opt-in to the Xbox One Console Update Preview which once installed will have the bitstream option that has been missing from the X1 line).  However
column4: this beta software is buggy and slow at times not even playing video that plays when the bitstream option is disabled.

column1: A further issue is that the drive tends to get noisy with 4k and some 3D discs.  Many videos will have stutters during playback
column2: and/or audio dropouts (search AVSForums for the X1S).

column1: Amazon Streaming: Xbox One S will output to the TV at 3840x2160/60p HDR
column2: but the picture quality is very soft compared to the Amazon app doing true 4k streaming on other devices instead appearing to be upscaled 1080p content (further reinforced by the app's own statement it is putting out 1080).

column1: Pressing 'Y' during playback shows the Amazon App states it is showing 'HD 1080p'.
The same videos played via the Amazon App on a Samsung TV and Roku 4 both show marked increases in quality
column2: being extremely sharper visually with a quality level expected from 4k.  The Amazon app on both of these devices displays 'HDR Ultra HD'.

column1: Notice the difference in playback rating:
The advantage this device has is of course the price and being gaming console as essentially a freebie."^2^February 26
